If I may enter a request, could you explain what makes unconscious 
decisions happen? For example, you go to sleep, then in the morning your 
mom yells at you for going back to sleep after she woke you up, but you 
have no recollection of such an event. She says that you got up, had your 
eyes open and talked to her, but when she came back you were sleeping.﻿
top_comment.author: Robert Blanchard

comments.text:
Your mind makes decisions with you all the time. The reason why you 
probably made a choice that you normally wouldn't make it because when 
you're asleep your brain is in a different chemical state (go to scishow 
(Hank hosts it too) and watch his episode on sleep) and sometimes lacks all 
the necessary information to make a decision. Memories are not automatic 
they need to be moved from short term memory and long term memory. If you 
are in to sleepy of a state it is likely that the memory just never made it 
to long term memory. It is a common theory that sleep is used to help 
organize and get rid of excess useless memories. So if you get woken up at 
the wrong time it's plausible your brain just erased it or deemed it 
irrelevant.
comments.author: literaryloser1

Therefore implies that your conclusion logically follows from your premise.

+Chanel McKinnon I beg for pardon, I was talking about the Italian 
'condition' of psychiatrists: here you have first to obtain what elsewhere

try to access to the specialization (Psychiatry in this case). In the first 
5-6 years of Medicine there is almost no training in psychological 
disciplines (naturally). However, when there is psychological training It 
concerns "only" about therapy/clinical psychology (or Psychodinamics, more 
often) and Psychoneuroendocrinology. Certainly a physician/ a psychiatrist 
would not be formed in the wide range of psychological fields. However, my 
point was that alot of psychiatrics here are only superficially formed even 
in that 'unique' psychology field, and they often prefer to use only drugs 
even if they have been theorically trained to practice psychotherapy 
(however notice that Psychotherapy is only an application of psychological 
knowledge and sciences, there's a big difference - what I'm saying is that 
who is trained in psychotherapy does not have necessarly a 'psychological 
knowledge' speaking in the "western meaning" of the term).
I do not know, certainly, what is the situation elsewhere.
Of course It is a 'delicate' matter. If it was up to me I would totally 
change the "Educational Offerings"/ training necessary for clinical 
psychologists and psychiatrists in order to 'unify' both of them (I'm 
referring to the Italian training). The students would fatigue like asses, 
but It could be useful for everyone and It would be harder and more 
selective (as any training should be). But this one is just a product of my 
illusions, It has nothing to do with my answer.

comments.text:
P.S.: dind't see the first of the two posts, I'm sorry.
However, I agree that the psychiatric DSM is a shitty thing. I don't like 
Psychiatry too. Actually, It could be really helpful if the practitioner 
had a very good education both in psychology and in medicine, and It could 
be helpful even If it is not 'perfect' (after all, clinicians and 
therapists need to acquire both qualitative and quantitative data, this 
book/manual should be considered only as a reference) but men, as always, 
easily ruin the thing. However Psychology is not a Mental Health field. Or 
better: It is when we talk about, lets say, Clinical Psy, 
School/Educational Psy, Military Psy, and in a sort of way Organizational 
Psy.
But all Psychology fields are born as research and application fields from 
Philosophy (like every science), from Medicine, Biology, Neuroscience, 
Engineering. Historically speaking, the 'health' aspect of Psychology was 
born later respect to the Psychophisics. I'm saying this because Its 
pourpose is to study cognition, behavior, emotions et ecetera
not necessarly to promote 'health' treatment and promotion in private 
offices.
Of course I understand that human and oter species' mind are really complex 
in a lot of the 'dimensions' we could consider It. But that's what it makes 
it fascinating and that leads us to improve techniques, tools, methodology 
introducing/using other fields such as (as you are saying) computation (in 
fact here we talk about cognitive psychology).

Certainly I'm all in too for scientific approach when and where is needed. 
And, yes, you are probably right: robotics, AI, compitational simulations 
et cetera even if they are still very young fields, can be easily 
considered as some of the most important and promising fields, today, 
necessary for the development of psychology and cognitive sciences (and, 
luckily, it seems to me that many psychologists worldwide are interested in 
these fields [not in Italy, here almost all of the students are interested 
in Clinical Psy - nothing bad about It, but the number of Clinical students 
is outstanding, especially compared to the number of Neuropsychologists, 
Ergonomists, Cognitive Neuroscientists, and people involved in Robotics, AI 
and similar fields]). Despite that, I think and it seems to me that the 
'scientifical' fields of Psychology are grasping and reaching an important 
quantity and quality of knoweldge experimentally substantial and 
'efficient'. 
My desire too is to study and work firstly in the fields of Psychobiology 
and in/with Neural Networks too (we could call It, i think, computational 
neuroscience). But here in Italy my chances after taking my degree are 
quite low cause here there aren't many opportuinites for wannabe 
researchers. Que sera sera.
However, don't be upset: Psychoanalisis can be fascinating, if it stayis 
where it belongs, but today I think there is no serious psychologist who 
gives credit to psychoanalisis (maybe some students, or therapists, and 
psychiatrists). But I'm afraid that Transpersonal psychologists (even if I 
would prefer to not call them this way) will forever exists. It can be 
really fascinating as long as it is seen as some kind of 'art' and, in a 
certain way, as a dimension of 'investigation' of spirituality (in these 
terms, I could say that I like the ancient alchemy, for example[as a 
profane], but only when humans let It stay where It belongs, turning It 
into trash).

However i can see what you are saying, I think. There are alot of buffoons 
(is this the word?) who try to get benefit by the confusing field of 
Psychology. And this is Psychologists fault: there is not a very large and 
strict control about pop-psychology. Everyday I walk into a library i would 
happily burn a lot of books that say "How to solve depression", "How to 
heal your mind", "How to defeat autism", "Be happy and life will smile at 
you", "How to break my balls everytime I see something like this".
comments.author: Nacht Reich

comments.text:
I should mention that i am all-in for a scientific aproach. I want a 
decent, testable and practical theory of the mind to crush the nonesensical 
psychoanalisis, slap the science-rejecting humanists in the face, and 
ridicule the transpersonal hippies untill they disapear.

At the moment i study and practice a neat new theroy, rooted in cybernetics 
and evolutionary theory, and i think it's the best proposal ever presented 
to explain the human mind.

Despite being tempted, seeing it appears to be way more advanced than 
anything else i've read or heard, to declare it the only reasonable 
alternative, i can't. It hasn't wistood the test of time. Within the entire 
lifespan of modern mental health, nothing has. Untill it does, until we 
have a good, testable, falsifiable, empirical and rational idea of what 
we're doing, we can't call it science.
comments.author: Sinclairelim

comments.text:
What you hate is superstition: believing you know when you actually do not.

But you have to understand the human mind is not very well understood. We 
have loose aproximations, that's all. Mental health is a mess. Even the 
standarized DSM is nothing but a list of syndroms superstitiously treated 
through drugs and linked to correlated chemical imbalances despite the fact 
that correlation is not causation. Hence why sometimes the superstitious 
humanist psychotherapist actually does better than the scientifically 
literate psychiatrist, who end up creating drug adicts more than healthy 
people. (Not all, i'm generalizing here.)

The amount of fields you mention sounds very impressive, but nonscienfic 
fields are huge and in ocacion much more effective than the scienfiic 
alternatives. Not only that, but they require much less preparation and are 
far less expensive, which is why psychotherapists often prefer them over 
more precice theories. And it works. This is why i say psychology is not 
science, i even dare extending that to mental health in general. Huge bits 
of it are plain superstition, and the rest of it, which is scientific, 
often is not the better alternative.

Psychology, eh, mental health as a whole is sooo young. Until a single 
epistemology and theory can unify it, and can be properly tested, calling 
science is not practical nor precise.
comments.author: Sinclairelim

comments.text:
Do not misunderstand me. I appreciate a lot all of the existing 
non-scientific (methodologically speaking) fields that I know about. What I 
like is the definition of Science as Knoweldge. And (actually - i think) no 
knowledge can be achieved without quantitative or qualitative data. What I 
do not like are the humans involved in all these fields, who try to make 
they appear what they are not. It seems too me like they are 'playing' with 
their readers with bullshits (it happens in 'science' and in 
'non-science'). That's one of the reasons why I hate psychoanalists, 
psychologists, physicists, biologists, 'teologists', bla bla bla. I 
appreciate alot humans/scientists/humanists who remain in their field of 
'expertising'; au contraire I do not like very much individuals like 
Dawkins and Feynman who tries (it seems to me, at least) 'cause they 
usually talk/talked about fields they do/did not know very much. For 
example, recently I'm reading "Neuropsicologia dell'esperienza religiosa", 
written by an italian neurpsychiatrist specilized in Neuropsychology. In 
this texts he talks about religion, spiritual dimension of human beings, 
neural, endocrinological and psychological (if we can mark a distinction) 
events caused by altered states of mind, religious and spiritual 
experiences (O.O.B.E. for example) and 'practices' (like meditation and 
prayers). And It does this in a very respectful way, without talking about 
what he 'doesn't know' and giving a lot of references for the interested 
ones.
comments.author: Nacht Reich

comments.text:
I make the disctinction between scientific psychology and that which is 
not, but although there are many names on the side of the scientific 
psychology, the non scientific branches are huge, and can't be brushed 
aside as "irrelevant".

There is value to the non scientific theories. Not at a theorical or 
epistemological level- that's where science shines, but (speaking as a 
psychotherapist) the methodology and techniques are very good, if you know 
where to use them.
comments.author: Sinclairelim

comments.text:
Nope. Psychoanalisis is a strange field that stands behind some sort of 
Philosophy with a 'Physician mind' (if i can say so). In fact a lot of 
psychiatrics are formed around psychodinamics principles. Moreover we could 
talk about Psychodinamics and Humanistic Psychology, but as I said they are 
'acquaintances'. I didn't say that they do not belong to the field of 
Psychology: in a simple way they are not born from experimental psychology, 
psychophisics, biological psychology, social psychology et cetera but they 
are born from the field of Psychoanalisis. So we could say that they are a 
sort of a 'strange' approach to the field of Psychology, but I think that's 
not correct (more or less technically speaking) including them in a total 
way.
Last but not least (what a shitty statement) as I said transpersonal 
psychology cannot be considered as a branch of Modern Psychology and 
Experimental Psychology in the Western World. In fact, if we want to speak 
in a very general way, we could say that Psychology exists by a long, long 
time, expecially in the Eastern Culture: but It did only in philosophical 
and introspective terms. This kind of 'doctrine' has nothing to do with 
what we call Scientific Psychology. Of course, it studies the 'mind', the 
altered states of consciousness and so on, but It doesn't use any of the 
scientific 'tools' or requirements and methods (speaking in rigorous 
terms). Moreover, as I said, it's probably 'just' a therapeutic practice, 
and therapy hasn't got much to do with Modern Psychology (we have to 
recognize that it depends on 'her', but not always and not necessarly in 
rigorous terms).

Wait, as far as I know Wundt and his followers were strongly opposed to 
introspection. They realized that introspection is highly subjective and 
therefore in conflict with their aim of establishing psychology as a 
natural science. Their main focus of study was perception which they 
studied by (for example) measuring reaction times.

Maybe I'm wrong, but I study Psychology so I'm pretty sure I'm not. Any 
response would be great :)﻿
top_comment.author: Moritz Schubert

comments.text:
+Moritz Schubert I understand that Wundt did use experimental 
introspection, or internal perception, which was intended to be rigidly 
controlled and replicable. Titchener then went to American with his 
Structuralism, which used introspection as the main tool of determining the 
distinct components of consciousness, having developed this from the ideas 
of Wundt. Wundt and Titchener both saw the importance of rigorous 
experimental methods.
comments.author: robinocracy

comments.text:
+Moritz Schubert You're right. Wundt always tried to come up with new and 
more objective methods of studying the mind. Titchener was really obsessed 
with structuralism, he claimed that it was the only 'real' method that 
should be used in psychology.
comments.author: Almir Xhangolli

comments.text:
I looked up the matter in Myers' "Psychology". The text in brackets is not 
actually from the book, but speculations from me.

It says there that Wundt tried to find the smallest elements of the human 
conciousness. [Since he tried to conduct psychology as a natural science, 
he probably thought that complex mental processes can be broken down to 
many tiny, undevidable processes similar to how in physics and chemistry we 
can break down everything to an atomic and molecular level.] Thitchener 
then went on to found structuralism, but Wundt wasn't part of that 
movement. So Wundt's and Thitchener's motivation was the same (they both 
tried to break down human thought into smaller elements), but the methods 
they used were vastly different. [Wundt, as far as I know, only used 
objective measures such as reaction time.]

If I remember correctly, Wundt was strongly opposed to introspection. So 
much so that he started a scientific debate either with one of his former 
students or Freud on that very same topic.
comments.author: Moritz Schubert

comments.text:
From what I remember from my psych classes, Wundt wasn't considered a 
structuralist. He called his approach 'voluntaristic'. I can't remember 
what that means.

It's true that he proposed an introspective psychology and was interested 
in consciousness and mental activity but he also acknowledged that 
introspection was unreliable, which led to him using objective measures 
like galvanic skin response and reaction times. So I think you're comment 
is correct.

top_comment.text:
I hate when I have to do this but... Psychology comes from the Ancient 
Greek and not Latin. Psyche and Logos is Soul+Study... same as 
Theos(God)+Logos=Theology. Zo'o (animal)+Logos= Zoology. 
Athropos(man)+Logos=Anthropology. Bios(Life)+Logos=Biology etc.﻿
top_comment.author: Constantine Krystallis

comments.text:
I agree that we can't go as far back as we would like. But you see Greek is 
the oldest recorded living language, so you can't go further back than that 
if you travel down that path. There are simply no records of the language 
it evolved from. But when something is so obvious a word like Psychology 
(psychologia in greek) it makes me wonder why you wouldn't quote the 
original and choose the mutation as the source when you are speaking about 
the roots of a word? I see that it won't be convenient to say it comes from 
the Latin that borrowed the Greek blah blah. But if you are speaking about 
the origin of a word, then speak about the origin. :-)

Again I am not saying this as a Greek Language fanboy here... The mistake 
just jumps out to me because I know the language. I always find it 
interesting to know where things come from.

Logos in Greek can mean a few things actually. Speach is the primary 
meaning. In this case, if you say "This person is a psychologist" it means 
this person speaks about the psyche, as in he researches the psyche, he 
studies it and is well able to speak about it. Logos also means reason, and 
congnitive thought. Psychologia is the science,research of the things of 
the soul. A "Logios", for example, is a person who has great experience 
with the written word.

Thanks for the chat.
comments.author: Constantine Krystallis

comments.text:
But if you want to get to the roots of words, how deep are you willing to 
go? Greek as a language evolved from something else, and that something as 
a language from something else, and so on.
This is why, like I said, when people (in a general definition, not in a 
discussion of etymology) say 'from the X language for Y'. Otherwise, *every* 
word would be 'from the X language which is from the A language which is 
from the B language which evolved out of the C language, which evolved from 
grunting'. 
It's not a discussion of greek or latin roots, but all words evolved from 
other words, which evolved from other languages. I mean, 'logy'/'logia' 
comes from the greek 'speak' not 'study' (right?) and yet, in english, we 
know 'logy' to mean only 'study of'.
comments.author: Zoe Rickard

comments.text:
I see what you are saying and as a "latinised Greek" it is fine with me. It 
is just that when you go to the trouble of refering to the origins of a 
word I suppose it is best to give the truest deffinition. See for me, being 
Greek it is obvious where it's origin is, and it isn't Latin. Latinised 
Greek? Ok sure. This is why in my initial post I say "I hate doing this" 
because I am not obssesed with all things Greek (and hate it when people 
are that way) but rather fond of getting as close to the truth as I can.
I think of it like this: It's like describing a load carrying collumn in a 
skyscrapper and you say: This collumn starts on the second floor (latin) 
when it is actually planted on the foundation (greek). It passes through 
the second floor but it doesn't come from it.
So you would say that the english word miserable comes from the french word 
miserable or the latin miserabilis? I would go straight to the Latin for 
example.
comments.author: Constantine Krystallis

comments.text:

comments.author: Jeremy Patton

comments.text:
Full disclosure: I study economics

It's hard to say where the line is between 'science' and 'not science,' 
so I've always seen this as a spectrum. On the 'hard science' side, it goes 
from physics to chemistry to biology, and continues down. I'd figure 
psychology is around the midpoint between science and liberal art. Studies 
which utilize functional neuroimaging and similar methods are naturally 
more 'scientific' than psychoanalysis. 

That said, I wouldn't put psychology in the same spheres as astrology or 
art history. "Science" is just a method of acquiring and organizing 
knowledge so as to make predictions, so it is technically science, albeit 
soft science.

That has to do with the evolution of Psychology itself. At first, it was 
just another branch of Philosophy - still in Ancient Greece, when its main 
focus was the study of the soul. Later on, it started to separate itself

top_comment.text:
He mentioned so many great thinkers but not the Buddha, who had taught (in 
my view) the most well-grounded "theory" of the workings of the mind, 
because he saw how the mind worked himself — not through divine 
intervention or thinking, but through conscious observation of the mind and 
its phenomena which arise due to causes and effects. The questions asked at 
1:36 can easily be answered by somebody who knows the basic workings of the 
mind... For example humans commit genocide for a number of (specific) 
reasons but it these boil down to the mind (due its lack of wisdom) giving 
rise to the unwholesome qualities of greed, hatred, and delusion. These 
things arise due to the mind's ignorance of the truth of reality: all 
things are changing, suffering arises when we attach to things, and 
everything is empty of self or inherent existence (because everything is 
conditioned by causes). Ignorance also translates to us not seeing the harm 
which is inherent in unwholesome actions. If we want to stop behaving 
badly, we should start reflecting on our actions and contemplating the 
pleasant and unpleasant results of engaging in them — that's wisdom, the 
pure awareness which lies in the heart of all of us and (for the ignorant) 
is obscured like the moon behind clouds. Unconscious mental phenomena are 
simply that: unconscious. In layman's terms, we're just unaware of these 
mental phenomena. But the Buddha and all of his disciples were able to 
train the mind to be mindful of mental phenomena — which is proof that 
these phenomena are totally observable in the here and now, which means 
that anybody can do it if they just start dedicating themselves to knowing 
things as they are.﻿

comments.text:
+tonbonthemon 

Ah OK. Forgive my blunt retort, I was concerned that you were implying some 
kind of pseudo-science. My bad. That’s why I felt the need to check, I’m 
not one for out-and-out offensive contention as there is nothing to be 
gained from it but I do like to be clear on what is being discussed. 

Anyway, I agree that analysis of cognitive processes and how we react to 
environmental stimuli is a healthy practice for those wanting to make 
changes to their deterministic tendencies. It is the kind of introspection 
that inevitably accrues wisdom if the data acquired is put to good use. 
Analysis of how we react in flux with our past experiences and current 
environment does shine a light on certain methods that we can practice that 
could help us to make the changes that we need. Then if it doesn’t work 
then we ask why, look at the variables and try something more appropriate 
as suggested by the information that we obtain from that analysis. 
Falsifiable testing. Psychology.

Now obviously I am philosophically biased in some respects being a 
materialist and do not agree with all of it's principles, but Buddhism has 
always been different to me. I don’t know a great deal about Buddhism, but 
I think that it is more of an ancient science decorated with stories as 
opposed to what is commonly regarded as a religion or faith system. As I 
understand it does not demand faith from followers or an acceptance of 
creationist theories, it merely encourages the practice of the 
introspective methods that encourage consideration, empathy and wisdom. 

What is understood as causal determinism and social behaviour coupled with 
probability and a few other bits and pieces is definitively similar to the 
focus of karma.

So yeah, why not the Buddha? I agree that there are some very valuable, 
beneficial points that can be extracted from the teachings. I can only 
assume that certain schools of thought are over-looked due to their 
religious connotations.
comments.author: Jubal Harshaw

comments.text:
+Jubal Harshaw Sure. Being aware of the pleasant/painful/neutral quality of 
experience, being aware of your perception of it, being aware of your 
intention towards the object of experience (passion, anger, etc), being 
aware of the mind's composure (is it restless or settled, dull or clear),

comments.text:
Jacob, I think the misunderstanding lies in the assumption that (1) karma 
is a metaphysical theory, and (2) the precepts are anything other than 
moral guidelines. (1) Karma is defined by the Buddha as "intention", so 
it's nothing crazy. When it comes to rebirth, that's something which, 
without a good understanding of Buddhist ideas, is difficult to understand. 
But look at it this way: what keeps you going in life? There's a desire to 
become something, an attachment to experience (whether you notice it or 
not; it's subtle), and mental intentions (karma). When the body dies and 
these things are still present (due to ignorance and attachment), the 
consciousness just keeps going. Is that really true? I don't know for sure, 
but right now I'm just taking it on faith. (2) The 5 precepts are used as 
restraints to prevent the practitioner from indulging in explicitly 
unwholesome actions. The 6th-10th precepts are more ascetic in nature. For 
the precept about luxurious beds and seats, that has to do with not 
indulging or developing a sense of pride over where you sit or sleep. For 
the precept on money, that has to do with preventing attachment to wealth.

Madame, you can find many resources on accesstoinsight.org. I don't know 
about simple resources, they might not even give you a good understanding 
since understanding Buddhism depends on your own personal practice... 
whatever you read is just conceptual. There's a book about you can find for 
free called "The Island", it's written by two Buddhist monks and contains 
many scriptural excerpts. It's primarily about Nirvana but it contains 
plenty of information on Buddhist principles.

comments.text:
In Buddhism, we observe the mind to understand the mind; we understand the 
mind to totally abandon qualities which cause suffering. You cannot turn 
these qualities off by the flick of a switch, you can only abandon them by 
giving rise to the appropriate mental conditions, and this can only be done 
with a truly deep and intuitive understanding of mental conditioning — not 
an understanding of chemical processes. If observing the mind is so easy, 
then why doesn't everybody do it? Why do people have such a hard time 
meditating?

captions.text:
That dream about the dinosaur in the leotard,
those times that you said that thing that

you know you shouldn't have said, or even
that thing you didn't even know you were gonna

say. The little cogs of your consciousness
cranking away, making your life possible,

making society function, all of the things
that you're so glad you can do and all of

the ones that you wish you could stop doing.
Excluding other human minds, your mind is

the most complicated piece of the universe
that humans currently know about. The rules

that govern it are mysterious and elusive.
Maybe our brains just aren't complex enough

to understand themselves. But that's not going
to stop us from trying!

The word 'psychology' comes from the Latin
for the "study of the soul." And while its

formal definition has evolved over the last
several decades, today we can safely call

it the science of behavior and mental processes.
The term 'psychology' wasn't coined until

around the turn of the sixteenth century,
and the practice that we would actually call

science today wasn't established until the
mid-1800s. But of course, humans have always

been curious about themselves and what's going
on up here. Aristotle pondered the seed of

human consciousness and decided that it was
in the heart, not the head -- being, as we

have seen quite a lot here on Crash Course,
absolutely and completely wrong.

Two thousand years ago, Chinese rulers conducted
the world's first psychological exams, requiring

public officials to take personality and intelligence
tests. And in the late 800s, Persian doctor

Muhammad ibn Zakariya al-Rhazes, also known
as Rhazes, was one of the first to describe

mental illness, and even treated patients
in what was essentially a very early psych
ward in his Baghdad hospital.

From the efforts of those early thinkers up
until today, the field of psychology has been

all about tackling some of the big questions:
How can humans do horrible things like commit

genocide and torture other humans, and how
come we know those things are horrible? Do

we have free will, or are we simply driven
by our environment, biology, and non-conscious

influences? What is mental illness, and what
can we do about it? And what is consciousness?

Or the notion of self? If I lose my awareness
of myself, am I still human?
I DON'T KNOW!

But over the next 6 months, these are the
questions that we're gonna be exploring together:

how our brains work, how they can break, how
they can be healed, why we behave the way

we do, even when we don't want to, and what
it means to be thinking and feeling and alive.
[Intro]

When hearing the word psychology, most people
probably think of a therapist listening to

a patient unpacking the details of his day
while reclining on a couch. Maybe that therapist

is wearing glasses, chewing on a cigar, stroking
his whiskered chin.

Admit it! If you're thinking about psychology,
you're probably picturing Freud.

Sigmund Freud was one of the most tremendously
influential and controversial thinkers of

his time, maybe of all time. His theories
helped build our views on childhood, personality,

dreams and sexuality. And his work fueled
a legacy of both support and opposition.

His life was long and spanned an important
swath of history from the American Civil War

to World War II. But like most great scientists,
Freud developed his revolutionary ideas by

building on the work of others, and of course
innovation in the field didn't stop with him.

In truth, psychology is one of the most wildly
diverse sciences in terms of the questions

it proposes, the methods it applies, and the
different schools of thought and disciplines
it contains.

Perhaps more than any other science, psychology
is just a big old integrated melting pot.

For instance, right around Freud's time, there
were a lot of different schools of thought

of about how the study of the human mind should
be tackled. Mainly, there were the ideas of
structuralism, functionalism and psychoanalysis.

Scientific psychology got its start in 1879
in Germany when physician Wilhelm Wundt set

up the first psychology laboratory at the
University of Leipzig just a few years after

publishing his Principles of Physiological
Psychology, considered the first true psychology
textbook.

Wundt and his student Edward Bradford Titchener
took cues from chemists and physicists and

argued that if those people could break down
all matter into simple elements or structures,
why couldn't they do the same for the brain?

They tried to understand the structures of
consciousness by getting patients to look

inward, asking them how they felt when they
watched the sun set, or smelled a coffee,
or licked a kitten, or whatever.

Titchener named this approach 'structuralism',
but despite its rigid sounding name, it really

relied so much on introspection that it became
too subjective. I mean, you may sense and

feel something different that I do, even if
we lick the same kitten. Psychologists, of

course, can't actually observe a patient's
inner thoughts or feelings, so ultimately,

the structuralist school of thought was fairly
short-lived.

By contrast, American physician and philosopher
William James proposed a different set of

questions, focusing on why we think and feel
and smell and lick, or whatever. Basically,

he focused on the function of behavior. This
approach, 'functionalism', was based on Charles

Darwin's idea that adaptive behaviors are
conserved throughout the evolutionary process.

James published his seminal book, The Principles
of Psychology, in 1890, defining psychology

as the science of mental life, just as Freud
was starting to flex his big brain.

Sigmund Freud began his medical career at
a Viennese hospital, but in 1886, he started

his own practice, specializing in nervous
disorders. During this time, Freud witnessed

his colleague Josef Breuer treat a patient
called Anna O with a new talking cure. Basically,

he just let her talk about her symptoms. The
more she talked and pulled up traumatic memories,

the more her symptoms were reduced. It was
a breakthrough, and it changed Freud forever.

From then on, Freud encouraged his patients
to talk freely about whatever came to mind,

to free associate. This technique provided
the basis for his career, and an entire branch
of psychology.

In 1900 he published his book The Interpretation
of Dreams, where he introduced his theory

of psychoanalysis. Now, you probably think
of psychoanalysis as a treatment -- the whole

patient on the couch scenario. And that's
definitely part of it. But Freud's concept

was actually a lot more complex than that,
and it was revolutionary.

A radical kernel of psychoanalysis was the
theory that our personalities are shaped by

unconscious motives. Basically Freud suggested
that we're all profoundly affected by mental
processes that we're not even aware of.

Now that sounds almost obvious to us now,
but part of the genius of Freud's theory was

that in 1900, it wasn't obvious at all. The
idea that our minds could be driven by something

that our minds themselves didn't know about
was hard to grasp. As hard as like, uhh, maybe

organisms evolving by natural selection. It
was abstract, invisible, and there was something
about it that seemed irrational.

But the other important part of Freud's theory
was that the unconscious, literally the thing

below consciousness, was still discoverable.
Even though you weren't aware of it, you could

come to understand it through a therapeutic
technique that used dreams, projections and

free association to root out repressed feelings
and and gain self-insight.

So what Freud was really saying was that mental
disorders could be healed through talk therapy

and self-discovery. And this was a really
big breakthrough. Because prior to this, people

with mental illnesses would be confined to
sanatoriums and at best given menial labor
to do and at worst, shackled to a bed frame.

After The Interpretations of Dreams, Freud
went on to publish over 20 more books and

countless papers with an iconic cigar in hand
all the while. He believed smoking helped

him think, but it also helped him get jaw
cancer. During the last sixteen years of his

life, he underwent at least thirty painful
operations while continuing to smoke.

By the late 1930s, the Nazis had taken over
Austria, and Freud and his Jewish family narrowly

escaped to England. By September 1939, the
pain in his cancerous jaw was too great and

a doctor friend assisted him in suicide through
morphine injection. He was eighty-three.

Whether you love him or hate him - and make
no mistake, plenty of people vehemently disagreed

with him - there is no question that Freud's
impact on psychology was monumental. While

competing theories in the young field of psychology
either fell away or evolved into something

else, psychoanalysis remains an important
concept and practice today.

The next big shake-up rolled in during the
first half of the 20th century when behaviorism

gained a higher profile. Heavy hitters like
Ivan Pavlov, John B. Watson, and B. F. Skinner

were key players here. They focused on the
study of observable behavior. You may remember

Skinner as the dude who put rats and pigeons
and babies in boxes and conditioned them to

perform certain behaviors. Right around when
Freud escaped to England, Skinner published

his Behavior of Organisms, ushering in the
era of behaviorism which remained all the
rage well into the 1960s.

The other major force at the time was, of
course, Freud's psychoanalysis, and its many

descendents collectively known as the psychodynamic
theories. These focused on the importance

of early experiences in shaping the unconsciousness
and how that process affects our thoughts,
feelings, behaviors, and personalities.

By the mid-20th century, other major forces
in psychology were also brewing -- schools

we'll explore later in this course including
humanist psychology, which focuses on nurturing

personal growth; cognitive science and neuroscience,
all of which contributed their own unique
takes on the study of mind.

Today's formal definition of psychology, the
study of behavior and mental processes, is

a nice amalgamation that pulls from all these
different schools of thought. It recognizes

the need for observing and recording behavior,
whether that's screaming, crying or playing

air saxophone to an imaginary audience, but
it also gives credit to our mental processes:

what we think and feel and believe while we're
tearing it up on our invisible instruments.

Because again, the point I really want you
to take home is that psychology is an integrative

science. Yes, folks still get grumpy and disagree
plenty, but the essence of the discipline

has everything to do with creating different
ways of asking interesting questions and attempting

to answer them through all kinds of data-gathering
methods. The human mind is complicated. There

is no single way to effectively crack it open;
it must be pried at from all sides.

Harvard astronomer Owen Gingerich has gazed
into the distant horizon of space, and even

he has acknowledged that the human brain is
by far the most complex physical object known

to us in the entire cosmos. And we all get
to have one! Of our very own! Just knocking
around right up in here.

We here at Crash Course are really excited
to spend the next several months delving into

the world of psychology -- how it applies
to our lives, our minds, and our hearts, and

how it deepens our understanding of each other,
our world, and ourselves.

Thanks for watching this first lesson in Crash
Course Psychology, and I'd like to especially

thank all of our Subbable subscribers, without
whom we would literally not be able to do

this. Would you like a personalized signed
Crash Course Chemistry Periodic Table, or

even to see yourself animated in one of our
episodes? To find out about these and other
perks, go to Subbable.com/CrashCourse.

And thanks to our crew. This episode was written
by Kathleen Yale and edited by Blake de Pastino.

Our psychology consultant is Dr. Ranjit Bhagwat,
our director and editor is Nicholas Jenkins.

The script supervisor was Michael Aranda who
was also our sound designer, and our graphic
team is Thought Cafe.
